headline.main: Former Astronaut to Head N.A.A.C.P. Campaign; N.A.A.C.P. Selects

results.snippet: The commander of the Gemini 4 and Apollo 9 space missions, James A. McDivitt, will head the 1982 campaign by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to raise $2.5 million from 1,300 corporations. Mr. McDivitt, a retired Air...
results.lead_paragraph: The commander of the Gemini 4 and Apollo 9 space missions, James A. McDivitt, will head the 1982 campaign by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to raise $2.5 million from 1,300 corporations. Mr. McDivitt, a retired Air Force general, is now with Rockwell International in Pittsburgh as senior vice president of strategic planning. Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the N.A.A.C.P., announced the appointment on a weekend trip to Pittsburgh. Mr. Hooks said that, although the N.A.A.C.P. has opposed the Reagan defense budget along with the cuts in social programs, he saw no inconsistency in its association with Rockwell, which has a $2.2 billion contract for the B-1 bomber.

headline.main: RESEARCHERS PONDER ITS USES FOR MAN

results.snippet: SOME time this month, the woodchuck wakes for good. Instead of emerging from its burrow for a brief look-see, as it is apt to do on Feb. 2 or any other randomly chosen day in midwinter, the woodchuck - along with bats, ground squirrels, hedgehogs,...
results.lead_paragraph: SOME time this month, the woodchuck wakes for good. Instead of emerging from its burrow for a brief look-see, as it is apt to do on Feb. 2 or any other randomly chosen day in midwinter, the woodchuck - along with bats, ground squirrels, hedgehogs, dormice and several other rodents and insectivores of cold and temperate zones -has come to the end of his winter hibernation and rejoins the world of the full-time mammals. Unlike, for example, bears, which merely doze and can awaken suddenly on provocation, true hibernators shut down shop for the duration. The metabolism of these animals drops to nearly nothing. Body temperature falls nearly to freezing. Heartbeat slows - in ground squirrels, for example, from 350 beats per minute to three or four. Stuffed with fat stored in the summer, they doze through months of snow and ice, which might otherwise starve them to death by depriving them of forage. In spring they emerge, thinner than before but ready to start a new season.

headline.main: NOW AND THEN, CONGRESS ALSO PONDERS THE FUTURE

results.snippet: Where have all the Government's futurists gone? A decade or so ago, when a thousand scholarly flowers bloomed, few seemed as promising, or as alluring to Federal officials, as the flower of futurism. The United States seemed to overcome its...
results.lead_paragraph: Where have all the Government's futurists gone? A decade or so ago, when a thousand scholarly flowers bloomed, few seemed as promising, or as alluring to Federal officials, as the flower of futurism. The United States seemed to overcome its antipathy to concerted planning and began seriously considering the shape the future might take. Even Congress, whose members seldom looked beyond the next election, started examining the implications of legislation in fields such as energy, the environment and social policy. Now, however, activity in the field has slowed to the point of stopping. ''Actually, it died somewhere in the 1970's,'' said Michael Marien, the editor of ''Futures Survey,'' a monthly abstract published by the World Future Society. ''Nobody announced its death, but it happened.'' Mr. Marien, who has been monitoring futures literature for the past dozen years, said the flood of books on trends and forecasts is down to a trickle.

results.snippet: Gen. Nikolai P. Kamanin, a prominent airman in the Soviet Union and the first director of astronaut training in his country's space program, is dead at the age of 73.   News of his death came yesterday when the Soviet Army newspaper Red Star...
results.lead_paragraph: Gen. Nikolai P. Kamanin, a prominent airman in the Soviet Union and the first director of astronaut training in his country's space program, is dead at the age of 73. News of his death came yesterday when the Soviet Army newspaper Red Star published an obituary signed by Dmitri F. Ustinov, the Soviet Defense Minister, and by Viktor Grishin, the Communist Party leader for Moscow. The article paid tribute to General Kamanin's role in selecting and training the country's corps of astronauts and organizing the first Soviet space flights. No details of his death were given.

results.snippet: The head-table guests, 62 of them, were a roll call of American business and industry. Even a random sampling was impressive: John R. Opel, chairman of IBM; Donald V. Seibert, chairman of J.C. Penney; Thornton F. Bradshaw, chief executive officer...
results.lead_paragraph: The head-table guests, 62 of them, were a roll call of American business and industry. Even a random sampling was impressive: John R. Opel, chairman of IBM; Donald V. Seibert, chairman of J.C. Penney; Thornton F. Bradshaw, chief executive officer of RCA; Richard J. Ferris, chief executive officer of United Airlines; John F. McGillicuddy, president of Manufacturers Hanover; Dr. Marina Whitman, vice president of General Motors, and Paula D. Hughes, vice president of Thomson McKinnon Securities. Sitting among them, on the uppermost level of the two-tier dais, was a woman who managed to make a purple ruffled dress look quietly dignified. She was Felice N. Schwartz; had it not been for her vision 20 years ago, 950 executives crowding the Waldorf-Astoria ballroom earlier this week would probably have been at home doing whatever executives do in their leisure hours.

headline.main: SPACE CARAVAN SETS UP SHOP FOR SHUTTLE IN NEW MEXICO

results.snippet: Shepherding a vital caravan of sophisticated hardware, scores of space technicians and managers hastily set up camp in a remote patch of desert today to prepare for the scheduled March 29 landing of the space shuttle Columbia.   Normally the gypsum...

byline.original: By JUDITH CUMMINGS, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Shepherding a vital caravan of sophisticated hardware, scores of space technicians and managers hastily set up camp in a remote patch of desert today to prepare for the scheduled March 29 landing of the space shuttle Columbia. Normally the gypsum floor of this southern New Mexico desert is desolate, part of an Army missile range and among some of the most closely guarded terrain in the nation. By 9 o'clock this morning, however, it was buzzing with helicopter manuevers, crackling with radio transmissions and popping with multicolored smoke bombs as the recovery crew simulated possible emergencies. Trial Runs Abbreviated Everything has not gone smoothly. Some critical recovery equipment, coming in by train from Edwards Air Force Base in California, was not used in the simulations at the Northrup landing strip. Officials attributed the change to delays in unloading.

headline.main: MEN IN THE NEWS: JACK R. LOUSMA

results.snippet: ''= I CONSIDER everything I've done for the last 20 years as training for this flight,'' Col. Jack R. Lousma of the Marine Corps said a few weeks before climbing into the space shuttle Columbia as commander of its third test mission.   For Colonel...
results.lead_paragraph: ''= I CONSIDER everything I've done for the last 20 years as training for this flight,'' Col. Jack R. Lousma of the Marine Corps said a few weeks before climbing into the space shuttle Columbia as commander of its third test mission. For Colonel Lousma, ''everything'' includes the following: - He has logged more than 3,600 hours in high-performance jet aircraft. He earned his wings as a marine pilot in 1960 and was assigned to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration as an astronaut in 1966. - Colonel Lousma trained as a member of support crews for three of the Apollo lunar missions and as a backup pilot for the Apollo spacecraft that linked up with a Soviet Soyuz craft in 1975.

headline.main: MEN IN THE NEWS:C. GORDON FULLERTON

results.snippet: ALTHOUGH this is Gordon Fullerton's first venture in space, it is not his first experience at the controls of the space shuttle. In 1977, he was a member of one of the two crews of astronauts who piloted the prototype shuttle Enterprise in a series...
results.lead_paragraph: ALTHOUGH this is Gordon Fullerton's first venture in space, it is not his first experience at the controls of the space shuttle. In 1977, he was a member of one of the two crews of astronauts who piloted the prototype shuttle Enterprise in a series of approach and landing tests at Edwards Air Force Base in California. A Boeing 747 piggybacked the Enterprise to a high altitude and released it. The astronauts then steered it unpowered to a touchdown on the desert floor, duplicating the critical final minutes of a real shuttle flight. With that experience behind him, Col. C. Gordon Fullerton was a natural choice for one of the four crews for the Columbia's orbital test flight program. Another qualification also seems to favor him for the mission. Unlike so many astronauts, who rose from the ranks of jet fighter pilots, Colonel Fullerton spent most of his Air Force career in multi-engine craft, bombers and cargo planes.

headline.main: SHUTTLE IS LOFTED INTO EARTH ORBIT FOR THIRD MISSION

results.snippet: Astronauts flew the space shuttle Columbia into orbit this morning for the third time, and despite one troublesome component on board, the project's officials said that the huge winged spaceship showed every sign of being able to complete its full...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Astronauts flew the space shuttle Columbia into orbit this morning for the third time, and despite one troublesome component on board, the project's officials said that the huge winged spaceship showed every sign of being able to complete its full seven-day mission. The liftoff, at 11 A.M., was the first in the shuttle development program to occur on the scheduled day, although it came an hour late. A faulty temperature sensor set back fueling operations during the night. As the 4.5-million-pound vehicle rose on a tail of orange flame, an estimated 750,000 people, one of the largest crowds to watch a launching, stood with upturned heads in the hot sun along the beaches and causeways here.

headline.main: 18-YEAR OLD SENDS HIS INSECTS INTO ORBIT

results.snippet: ALONG with two astronauts, other forms of life rode aboard the space shuttle as it headed into orbit yesterday - 10 moths and 10 honeybees.   The insects, fulfilling the proposal of an 18-year-old Minnesota student, will be observed attempting to...
results.lead_paragraph: ALONG with two astronauts, other forms of life rode aboard the space shuttle as it headed into orbit yesterday - 10 moths and 10 honeybees. The insects, fulfilling the proposal of an 18-year-old Minnesota student, will be observed attempting to fly in the weightless environment of the Columbia as it orbits the earth. An astronaut will keep track of the insects' efforts both visually and with a camera.

results.snippet: A Question of Trade   W hen is promoting cigarette sales not increasing hazards to health? When it is done abroad in the name of lowering trade barriers.   Edwin L. Meese 3d, counselor to the President, was asked at a health meeting whether an...

byline.original: By Francis X. Clines and Warren Weaver Jr

results.lead_paragraph: A Question of Trade W hen is promoting cigarette sales not increasing hazards to health? When it is done abroad in the name of lowering trade barriers. Edwin L. Meese 3d, counselor to the President, was asked at a health meeting whether an Administration trade team that is trying to loosen restrictions on cigarette advertising in Japan wasn't running contrary to the Surgeon General's most recent warnings on smoking. Not at all, replied the White House aide. The Japanese now require American cigarettes to be advertised in English, which is ''a significant example of a trade barrier,'' something the mission is trying to overcome.

headline.main: FIERCE SANDSTORM DELAYS THE RETURN OF SPACE SHUTTLE

results.snippet: A blinding sandstorm, driven by winds reaching 55 miles an hour, raged across the space shuttle's desert landing site today and forced a one-day postponement of the Columbia's return to the earth.   A new attempt is to be made Tuesday morning, with...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: A blinding sandstorm, driven by winds reaching 55 miles an hour, raged across the space shuttle's desert landing site today and forced a one-day postponement of the Columbia's return to the earth. A new attempt is to be made Tuesday morning, with Northrup Strip on the white gypsum flats here still designated as the primary landing site. But if the winds come up again, the Columbia will be diverted to a touchdown on the concrete runway at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Project officials said that every effort would be made to conclude the mission here because they did not want the space shuttle to land on a relatively narrow runway until it had landed at least four times on broad desert floors.

headline.main: THE SHUTTLE: PERFECTION ELUDES NASA BUT CONFIDENCE GROWS

results.snippet: Last November, as the second flight of the space shuttle Columbia was ending, some of the space agency's top engineers looked back at the string of equipment failures that had afflicted the first two flights. Having just been forced to cut the...

byline.original: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Last November, as the second flight of the space shuttle Columbia was ending, some of the space agency's top engineers looked back at the string of equipment failures that had afflicted the first two flights. Having just been forced to cut the second mission short because of one such failure, they conceded that they had created a machine so complex that they had not yet mastered it. So until they developed more confidence, they said, they would have to treat the space shuttle cautiously and gingerly. Last night, as Columbia was preparing to land after completing all the major tasks of its third and next-to-last test flight, Neil Hutchinson, one of the three flight directors who had taken eighthour turns at running the mission, offered this assessment of how far things had come during the last week: ''You have to believe that we're a gigantic step closer to having a vehicle that doesn't require as much babysitting.'' That, said Mr. Hutchinson, ''is what the operations thing is all about.'' None of his assessment was negated by today's one-day postponement of the shuttle's landing, made necessary by high winds at the White Sands, N.M., landing site. In fact, the postponement and the subsequent decision to consider landing at Kennedy Space Center in Florida were taken as evidence of the flexibility with which the shuttle may be able to operate.

headline.main: ASTRONAUTS MUST CHOOSE ONE OF THREE RUNWAYS

results.snippet: As the space shuttle Columbia searches for a place to land today, it has three primary options, each with strengths and drawbacks.  If the shuttle lands on the concrete runway at Edwards Air Force Base in California, one of the two sites under...
results.lead_paragraph: As the space shuttle Columbia searches for a place to land today, it has three primary options, each with strengths and drawbacks. If the shuttle lands on the concrete runway at Edwards Air Force Base in California, one of the two sites under consideration if wind conditions rule out a landing at the White Sands Missile Range, there will be no immediate way to unload its various fuels, some of which are lethal or highly volatile. Should the landing be at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, as seems more likely, extensive servicing of the vehicle will be possible. Indeed, when the Columbia was launched March 22, the 15,000-foot concrete runway there was prepared to accept a ''returnto-launch-site abort'' if trouble developed in the first few minutes. And, under current plans, the Kennedy strip will eventually serve as one of the two routine landing sites, enabling shuttles to return there directly and be prepared for subsequent flights. On the other hand, Kennedy has a single runway flanked by a moat.

headline.main: A CANAVERAL, DEJECTION AND LOOK TO THE FUTURE

results.snippet: The only things that landed on the Kennedy Space Center runway here today were a jet trainer, a few crows and several squadrons of butterflies.   There was a possibility that the space shuttle Columbia might land here, too, until the wind quieted...

byline.original: By JAMES P. STERBA, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The only things that landed on the Kennedy Space Center runway here today were a jet trainer, a few crows and several squadrons of butterflies. There was a possibility that the space shuttle Columbia might land here, too, until the wind quieted at the White Sands Missile Range's Northrup Airstrip and permitted the landing there. The fact that the Columbia did not land at Cape Canaveral, however, did not mean that the efforts of the ground crews here were wasted. In most shuttle flights of the future, Cape Canaveral, whose runway looks like the flat top of an aircraft carrier compared with the Western sand flats where the Columbia has been landing, will be the regular landing site for nonmilitary missions.

headline.main: SHUTTLE RETURNS AFTER 8-DAY TRIP, LANDING IN DESERT

results.snippet: The third and longest test flight of the space shuttle Columbia ended successfully today with the grace of a soaring eagle dropping out of the sky as the craft came to a smooth landing on a desert of glistening white gypsum sand.   After a...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The third and longest test flight of the space shuttle Columbia ended successfully today with the grace of a soaring eagle dropping out of the sky as the craft came to a smooth landing on a desert of glistening white gypsum sand. After a 50-minute descent from its orbit of the earth, the winged spaceship hove into view in the blue sky over Mockingbird Gap in the San Andres Mountains, glided east over the desert basin, made a wide right turn and, issuing a sonic boom at 20,000 feet, lined up for the landing. Col. Jack R. Lousma of the Marine Corps, the commander, took over manual control at 100 feet and eased the Columbia's rear wheels onto the gypsum surface a few seconds short of 11:05 A.M. The nose reared up and back like a dragon challenged in combat, possibly a result of Colonel Lousma's trying to brake the rollout or from a sudden gust of wind. Flight controllers could not be sure until they talked to the astronauts. Sandstorm Delayed Landing Then Colonel Lousma, with Col. C. Gordon Fullerton of the Air Force, brought the 100-ton craft to a stop, concluding a mission of eight days and five minutes. The flight was extended an extra day because a sandstorm here made a scheduled landing Mondayimpossible.
